newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada tobacco maker squares off against province.
newsitem.headline: Canada tobacco maker squares off against province.

text.p: One of Canada's biggest tobacco companies signalled on Thursday it would fight back against British Columbia's efforts to force the industry to pay medical costs for treating smokers.
"Lawsuits commenced against (Rothman's) will be vigorously defended," Rothman's Benson and Hedges Chief Executive Joe Heffernan wrote in a letter to British Columbia Health Minister Joy MacPhail.
He added in the letter released on Thursday that Rothman's hoped to open discussions with the Canadian province on "tobacco issues."
British Columbia officials were not immediately available for comment.
British Columbia last month introduced legislation laying the groundwork for it to file a class action suit against tobacco companies to recoup medical costs.
The action would be similar to that taken by 37 U.S. states and would make British Columbia the first government outside the United States to take such a step.
U.S. tobacco companies and the states recently announced a proposed $386.5 billion settlement of those claims.

Heffernan said it was unlikely that "recent events in the United States can easily be replicated in British Columbia...due to Canada's significantly different history of tobacco regulation and taxation."

He rejected the province's demands, which included a public acknowledgement by the company that smoking was addictive, changes to marketing practices and the payment of costs for treating smokers and smoking prevention programs.

The British Columbia government has said it expects to file a lawsuit against tobacco manufacturers in coming months. Before it does, it wants the tobacco industry to compensate it voluntarily for tobacco-related illness and smoking prevention programs.
MacPhail has estimated the province's direct and indirect medical costs related to smoking and the price of smoking prevention programs at about C$1.6 billion ($1.2 billion) a year.
Toronto-based Rothman's, Canada's second biggest cigarette maker, is 60 percent-owned by Rothmans Inc. and 40 percent by Philip Morris Cos Inc..
Rothmans Inc. is a unit of Rothmans International Plc RIN_.L, which is owned by Swiss luxury goods holding company Cie Financiere Richmont AG.
